ak

Why Usability Matters

Usability testing can be one of the best ways to make your website easier to use.

This article is going to focus on my reading of Rocket Surgery Made Easy by Steve Krug and the ChiScore application that I built here at 8th light.

So what is usability testing?

Watching people try to use what your creating, with the intention of (a) making it easier to use or (b) proving that it is easy to use.

There are two different types of testing available each with own implications:

Qualitative

  • Deals with descriptions
  • "Do it yourself"
  • Gain insight through context
  • Capture emotion

Quantitative

  • Deals with numbers
  • Requires larger sample size
  • Data/fact driven
  • Prove something

I'm more interested in gaining insight through qualitative research so I can improve what I'm building and less on statistics. The whole idea behind Rocket Surgery Made Easy is that you can do qualitative testing yourself or with a few people.

ChiScore

I recently had the opportunity to work on an application with Brian Pratt and Rylan Dirksen. It's called ChiScore and was built to check-in teams for the Chiditarod.

Chiditarod (think Iditarod) is Chicago's Epic Urban Iditarod. A charity food drive, beauty pageant, costumed shopping cart race, talent show, fundraiser and chaos generator all in one. And probably the world's largest mobile food drive, benefitting the Greater Chicago Food Depository.

My role in this project was to design and implement the front end. I decided to challenge myself by making the application responsive too!

Brian wanted ChiScore to be clean and simple. I started with some sketches before picking my fonts and colors. These days, I do most of my desigining in browser. Check out The Post PSD Era by Brad Frost. I rarely do mockups in Photoshop or Illustrator anymore.

Here is what I came up with:

I didn't realize it at the time, but I was going to get my first opportunity to do some qualitative usability testing.

ChiScore Usability Testing

We finally had a working protype (with responsive elements) and it was time to show it off to the Chiditarod team for feedback. This was such a rewarding experience.

Brian presented to a room of over 40 voluteeers along with the oraganizer. I went around the room and helped the voluteeers load up ChiScore in their browsers. At that moment, I realized I just gain a room full of test participants.

In usability testing, we call the people we're observing "test participants," not "test subjects," to remind ourselves that we really aren't testing them — we're testing the thing they're using.
